title: Course Overview and Workflow Setup
section: What you’ll be able to do by the end of this course
text:
What you’ll be able to do by the end of this course

Build software that calls model APIs (Gemini) safely and reliably
Design tool-using and multi-step agent workflows
Test and evaluate non-deterministic components
Ship a final project with clear limitations + documentation

title: Course Overview and Workflow Setup
text:
How we’ll work

Course hub site: schedule, policies, resources
GitHub Classroom repos: where graded work happens
AI use: allowed (and expected) with transparency

title: Course Overview and Workflow Setup
text:
Tools for Week 1

Python 3.13.x
venv + pip
VS Code (recommended)
Git + GitHub

title: Course Overview and Workflow Setup
text:
GitHub Classroom: what “submission” means

Accept the assignment link
Make changes in your assignment repo
Commit + push to GitHub before the deadline
Check ✅/❌ next to your latest commit for autograding results

title: Course Overview and Workflow Setup
text:
Setup checklist (high level)

Install VS Code
Install Git
Install Python 3.13.x
Clone your A0 repo
Create .venv, install dependencies
Commit + push a small change

title: Course Overview and Workflow Setup
text:
Expectations and norms

You are responsible for keeping your repos private unless instructed otherwise
Don’t commit secrets (API keys) — use .env locally
Ask for help early; include exact error messages

title: Course Overview and Workflow Setup
text:
Next steps

Read the syllabus + policies
Complete Day 1 setup
Start A0 (Setup Verification)

title: Initial Setup (Windows)
text:
This guide installs the core tools you need for the course. You only need to do this once.

Course standard: Python 3.13.x (we’ll support/debug primarily on 3.13). Download: https://www.python.org/downloads/latest/python3.13/






Windows 10/11
A GitHub account (the same one you’ll use to accept GitHub Classroom assignments)







https://code.visualstudio.com/download




Run the installer.
Accept defaults unless you know you want something else.
Recommended: enable “Add to PATH”.

(Official Windows setup doc: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/setup/windows)



Open VS Code from the Start menu.







Use either official source:

https://git-scm.com/download/win
https://gitforwindows.org/




Accept defaults unless you know you need different settings.



Open PowerShell and run:
git --version



git config --global user.name "First Last"
git config --global user.email "you@school.edu"
git config --global --list







https://www.python.org/downloads/latest/python3.13/



When running the installer: 1. Check “Add python.exe to PATH” 2. Keep pip included (default) 3. Keep the Python launcher (py) enabled if offered (default)



Close and reopen PowerShell, then run:
python --version
py --version
pip --version





In VS Code, go to Extensions:

Python (Microsoft)

Optional:

GitHub Pull Requests and Issues (GitHub)





For each assignment, follow the GitHub Classroom Workflow Guide.

title: Initial Setup (Windows)
section: Git not found in VS Code
text:
Git not found in VS Code

Install Git for Windows (https://git-scm.com/download/win)
Quit and restart VS Code
Verify:
git --version

title: Initial Setup (Windows)
section: python not recognized or opens Microsoft Store
text:
python not recognized or opens Microsoft Store

Install Python 3.13.x from https://www.python.org/downloads/latest/python3.13/
Make sure Add to PATH is checked
Restart PowerShell and verify:
python --version
py --version

title: Initial Setup (Windows)
text:
PowerShell won’t run scripts (execution policy)
Use Command Prompt terminal in VS Code instead, or (advanced) allow local scripts:
Set-ExecutionPolicy -Scope CurrentUser RemoteSigned

title: Initial Setup (Windows)
section: If you’re stuck, include these in your help request
text:
If you’re stuck, include these in your help request
git --version
python --version
py --version

title: GitHub Classroom Workflow
text:
This guide covers the steps you’ll follow for each GitHub Classroom assignment:

Accept the assignment and clone the repo
Create a virtual environment and install dependencies
Do the work
Commit and push (submit)


Prerequisite: Complete the one-time setup first: Initial Setup (Windows) | Initial Setup (macOS)






Click the Classroom invite link (from the Assignments page or Schedule).
Click Accept assignment.
GitHub creates a repo for you and takes you to it.





Copy the repo HTTPS URL from GitHub (click Code → HTTPS).

Windows (VS Code)Windows (Terminal)macOS (Terminal)



In VS Code: Ctrl+Shift+P → Git: Clone
Paste the URL
Pick a folder
Open the repo when prompted



cd C:\Users\YourName\Documents
git clone <PASTE-REPO-URL-HERE>
cd <REPO-FOLDER>
code .


cd ~/Documents
git clone <PASTE-REPO-URL-HERE>
cd <REPO-FOLDER>
code .







Open a terminal in VS Code: Terminal → New Terminal

Windows (PowerShell)Windows (Command Prompt)macOS


py -3.13 -m venv .venv
.\.venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1
python -m pip install --upgrade pip
pip install -r requirements.txt


If PowerShell blocks the activation script:
py -3.13 -m venv .venv
.\.venv\Scripts\activate.bat
python -m pip install --upgrade pip
pip install -r requirements.txt


python3.13 -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate
python -m pip install --upgrade pip
pip install -r requirements.txt






WindowsmacOS


python --version
where python
The where python output should show a path inside .venv.


python --version
which python
The which python output should show a path inside .venv.








If the repo has tests:
pytest -q
Or run a quick Python check:
python -c "print('Hello from Python!')"




Complete the assignment according to the instructions in the repo’s README.




Typical “submission” is commit + push. Autograding (if enabled) runs after you push.

VS Code UITerminal



Open the Source Control panel (left sidebar)
Stage changes (click + next to files)
Enter a commit message
Click Commit
Click Sync Changes (pushes to GitHub)



git status
git add .
git commit -m "Complete submission"
git push



After pushing, check your repo on GitHub. If autograding is enabled, you’ll see a ✅ or ❌ next to your commit.

title: GitHub Classroom Workflow
text:
git push permission/auth errors

Make sure you accepted the assignment with the correct GitHub account
Retry push and complete the browser sign-in flow if prompted
Check that the repo URL matches your GitHub username

title: GitHub Classroom Workflow
text:
PowerShell won’t activate .venv (execution policy)
Use Command Prompt instead:
.\.venv\Scripts\activate.bat
Or (advanced) allow local scripts in PowerShell:
Set-ExecutionPolicy -Scope CurrentUser RemoteSigned

title: GitHub Classroom Workflow
text:
requirements.txt not found
Not all assignments have a requirements.txt. Skip the pip install -r requirements.txt step if the file doesn’t exist.

title: GitHub Classroom Workflow
text:
Tests failing after push

Read the error message in the GitHub Actions log
Fix the issue locally
Commit and push again

title: GitHub Classroom Workflow
text:
Quick reference: common commands








Task
Windows (PowerShell)
macOS




Create venv
py -3.13 -m venv .venv
python3.13 -m venv .venv


Activate venv
.\.venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1
source .venv/bin/activate


Deactivate venv
deactivate
deactivate


Install deps
pip install -r requirements.txt
pip install -r requirements.txt


Run tests
pytest -q
pytest -q


Commit all
git add . && git commit -m "msg"
git add . && git commit -m "msg"


Push
git push
git push

title: Assignments
text:
Assignment calendar (overview)

Weeks 1–10: individual “build” assignments (A0–A8, plus possibly A9)
Weeks 11–15: final project work + checkpoints
Week 16: final presentations

(Your instructor will keep the authoritative details below.)

text:
Final project (team repo)

Team repo creation

When: (e.g., Week 8)
How: GitHub Classroom group assignment (one repo per team)



Project checkpoints (typical)

Proposal: Week 9 (Tue)
Plan: Week 12 (Tue)
Midpoint demo: Week 12 (Sun)
Ethics memo: Week 14 (Tue)
Final submission: Week 16 (Fri)

(Replace with your confirmed milestone dates.)

title: Assignments
text:
Grading notes (keep it short here)

Autograding checks correctness and basic engineering requirements.
Some assignments include a short reflection or demo component.
See the Syllabus for grading weights.

title: Assignments
text:
FAQ: “My assignment says Not Submitted”
GitHub Classroom submission status is often tied to the assignment deadline/cutoff. In most cases, pushing commits before the deadline is what matters.
If you have pushed and are unsure, check:

your repo shows your latest commit on main
autograding checks (✅/❌) next to your commit (if enabled)

title: Creating with AI in the Loop
text:
Welcome! This is the course hub for Creating with AI in the Loop.
If you’re ever unsure where to find something, start here.

title: Creating with AI in the Loop
text:
What you should do first (Week 1)

Read the Syllabus and the AI Use Policy.
Follow the Initial Setup (Windows) or Initial Setup (macOS).
Accept A0 — Setup Verification using the link on the Assignments page.
Make sure you understand how “submission” works (commit + push).

title: Creating with AI in the Loop
section: What this course is about (short version)
text:
What this course is about (short version)
You will learn to:

use AI tools effectively in a software development workflow
build software that calls model APIs (Gemini) and uses tools/data
test and evaluate non-deterministic components
ship a final project with clear design choices and limitations

title: Creating with AI in the Loop
section: Course “defaults” (so you don’t have to guess)
text:
Course “defaults” (so you don’t have to guess)

Python: 3.13.x (supported)

Environment: venv + pip

Repo workflow (early weeks): commit to main

Autograding: usually runs on push (check ✅/❌ on GitHub)

title: Initial Setup (macOS)
text:
This guide installs the core tools you need for the course. You only need to do this once.

Course standard: Python 3.13.x (we’ll support/debug primarily on 3.13).






macOS (recent version)
Admin access for installs
A GitHub account





Open Terminal and run:
xcode-select --install
Verify:
git --version


git config --global user.name "First Last"
git config --global user.email "you@school.edu"
git config --global --list





Run the official installer:
/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"
If the installer prints a line that starts with eval "$(...)", copy/paste it into Terminal (this adds Homebrew to your PATH).
Verify:
brew --version




Install:
brew install python@3.13
Verify:
python3.13 --version
python3.13 -m pip --version

If python3.13 is not found, run:
brew info python@3.13
and follow the “caveats” it prints (Homebrew will tell you what to add to your PATH).








Download: https://code.visualstudio.com/download
Drag Visual Studio Code.app to Applications
Open VS Code once




brew install --cask visual-studio-code





In VS Code, go to Extensions:

Python (Microsoft)

Optional:

GitHub Pull Requests and Issues (GitHub)



In VS Code:

Cmd+Shift+P → Shell Command: Install ‘code’ command in PATH

Verify in Terminal:
code --version





For each assignment, follow the GitHub Classroom Workflow Guide.

title: Initial Setup (macOS)
text:
Homebrew: brew: command not found
Re-run the PATH line the installer printed (the eval ... line), then restart Terminal and try:
brew --version

title: Initial Setup (macOS)
section: Python 3.13 not found (python3.13: command not found)
text:
Python 3.13 not found (python3.13: command not found)
Run:
brew info python@3.13
and follow the “caveats” (it tells you exactly what to add to your PATH). Then open a new Terminal and retry:
python3.13 --version

title: Initial Setup (macOS)
section: VS Code: code: command not found
text:
VS Code: code: command not found
In VS Code:

Cmd+Shift+P → Shell Command: Install ‘code’ command in PATH Restart Terminal.
